cs113.calendar.simpleview
Class CommandLineEngine

java.lang.Object
  cs113.calendar.simpleview.CommandLineEngine

public class CommandLineEngine
extends java.lang.Object

Handles a set of stored commands indexed by name. After creating the CommandLineEngine, the client can add commands to it with addAction(). These commands are stored by their name and can be invoked with doCommandLine(); Commands can be given regex formats for argument parsing.

Author:
Owen Healy

Constructor Detail

CommandLineEngine

public CommandLineEngine()
Creates an empty CommandLineEngine, with no commands. Commands may then be added with addAction().

Method Detail

addAction

public void addAction(java.lang.String name,
                      java.lang.String argFormat,
                      CommandLineAction action)
Adds an action to the pool of actions that we can handle.

Parameters:
name - Key that identifies this action.
action - The action to be added.

doCommandLine

public void doCommandLine(Controller controller,
                          java.lang.String command,
                          java.util.List<java.lang.String> args)
                   throws NoSuchCommandException
Finds the named command, then invokes it, passing along the specified arguments.

Parameters:
controller - The controller on which to apply the action.
command - The name of the command to invoke.
args - The arguments to the command.
Throws:
NoSuchCommandException - if we can't find an appropriate CommandLineAction.

doCommandLine

public void doCommandLine(Controller controller,
                          java.lang.String text)
                   throws NoSuchCommandException,
                          CommandFormatException
Finds the first token. Uses this as a command name, and identifies the format string for the arguments, along with the implementation to be called. Parsers the remainder of the string according to the prescribed format, and then invokes the command.

Parameters:
controller - The controller on which to apply the action.
text - The text given to us.
Throws:
NoSuchCommandException - if we can't find the command name in our table.
CommandFormatException - if the text does not conform to the expected format.
